sinks.name: TEE_CreatePersistentObject
sinks.reason: Tainted storageID can select unintended backend or behavior, impacting security policy

sinks.name: TEE_CreatePersistentObject
sinks.reason: Tainted objectID pointer controls the identifier namespace; can cause unauthorized overwrite/collision

sinks.name: TEE_CreatePersistentObject
sinks.reason: Tainted objectIDLen may cause unexpected identifiers or errors; integrity/policy risk

sinks.name: TEE_CreatePersistentObject
sinks.reason: Tainted flags can enable overwrite or unintended access permissions; policy violation

sinks.name: TEE_CreatePersistentObject
sinks.reason: Tainted attributes/object handle could inject unintended key/material into the persistent object

sinks.name: TEE_CreatePersistentObject
sinks.reason: Tainted initialData pointer allows attacker-controlled data to be persisted; integrity risk

sinks.name: TEE_CreatePersistentObject
sinks.reason: Tainted initialDataLen can cause resource exhaustion/DoS or unexpected data size persisted

sinks.name: TEE_CreatePersistentObject
sinks.reason: Tainted output handle location could be invalid; may cause runtime errors if not validated

sinks.name: TEE_GetObjectInfo1
sinks.reason: Writes object metadata into caller-provided buffer which could be shared with Normal World, enabling unencrypted data exposure

sinks.name: TEE_Malloc
sinks.reason: Tainted size can cause under/overallocation, integer overflow in size computation, or DoS, leading to subsequent memory safety issues

sinks.name: TEE_ReadObjectData
sinks.reason: Destination buffer may be shared with Normal World, causing data exposure

sinks.name: TEE_ReadObjectData
sinks.reason: Tainted size can trigger buffer overflow or OOB write into destination buffer

sinks.name: TEE_WriteObjectData
sinks.reason: Source buffer is read and persisted; if tainted or invalid, can cause unintended data persistence or out-of-bounds read from TA memory

sinks.name: TEE_WriteObjectData
sinks.reason: Size controls how many bytes are read from the buffer; tainted size can cause over-read of TA memory and unintended data persistence
